section.title: Description
section.para: This course covers the development of the service tier using JavaEE standards, focusing on Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB). It will cover characteristics required by a service tier and why we need EJB and technologies associated with EJB. This course covers development use cases related to building and deploying service tiers and deploying to a JavaEE application server. The student will make full use of Maven, and IDE (default is Eclipse) and an application server (JBoss/Wildfly) and a relational database (H2).

The material currently covers standards adopted as of JavaEE 6 (JPA 2.0, EJB 3.1, and JMS 1.1) and is being actively updated with information from JavaEE 7 (JPA 2.1, EJB 3.2, and JMS 2.0). The development environment used in class is JavaSE and JavaEE 7-compliant.

Using modern development tools, commercial persistence providers, and application servers, students will design and implement several significant programming projects using the above mentioned technologies and deploy them to a Java EE environment that they will manage.

section.title: Student Background
section.para: The course is open to all levels of interest in developing EJB solutions. Since there are no required assignments or tests -- the student will have the freedom to get out of the course according to their experience level and the amount of work they put into it. However, the course is specifically designed for students comfortable with JavaSE development and lectures and exercises will be primarily geared at that level of audience.

section.title: Required Software
section.para: This course will make heavy use of development tools (Git, Maven 3, JUnit, Log4j, and Eclipse), a database (H2 Database Engine), persistence provider (Hibernate), and application server (JBoss/Wildfly 8). Students are strongly encouraged to establish a local development environment. Detailed instructions for setup are part of the first exercise (Development Environment Setup).

section.title: References
section.para: The "optional" texts are current and relevant to the platform we will be using. However, the course will not make any explicit reference to them. All material will be available in example form froms this course.
